content:
The Act may be cited as the "Healthy Fisheries through Better Science Act" and defines stock assessment. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act defines stock assessment as evaluating the past, present, and future status of a fish stock, including life history characteristics and fishing for the stock. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act defines stock assessment as evaluating the past, present, and future status of a fish stock, including life history characteristics and fishing for the stock. SEC. 3. STOCK ASSESSMENT PLAN. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act is amended to include a Stock Assessment Plan requiring the Secretary to develop and publish a schedule for updating stock assessments for all fish stocks under a fishery management plan. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act is amended to include a Stock Assessment Plan that mandates regular updates of stock assessments for fish stocks under a management plan. This includes conducting new assessments every 5 years or as specified by the Secretary, and establishing schedules for initial assessments for stocks without previous assessments. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act now includes a Stock Assessment Plan that requires regular updates of stock assessments for fish stocks. The plan mandates completion of initial stock assessments within 3 years of publication in the Federal Register, unless a different timeframe is justified by the Secretary. Additionally, the plan aims to identify data and analysis, particularly for recreational fishing, that could improve the accuracy of future stock assessments, potentially sourced from non-governmental entities like fishermen, fishing communities, universities, and research institutions. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act now includes a Stock Assessment Plan that requires regular updates of stock assessments for fish stocks. A waiver of the stock assessment requirement is allowed if the Secretary determines it unnecessary and justifies in the Federal Register notice. The Secretary of Commerce must issue the first stock assessment plan within 1 year of the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. IMPROVING SCIENCE. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act is being amended to incorporate information from various sources for effective fisheries management. This includes data from governmental and nongovernmental entities like State and Federal agencies, fishermen, universities, and research institutions. Additionally, there is a focus on improving data collection and analysis to inform conservation and management measures. The Magnuson-Stevens Act is being amended to include data from nongovernmental sources like fishermen and universities for better fisheries management. Guidelines will be developed to incorporate this data into decision-making processes. The Magnuson-Stevens Act is being amended to include data from nongovernmental sources for fisheries management. Guidelines will be developed for data collection, analysis, and establishing a registry of providers. The Secretary and Regional Fishery Management Councils will use approved data and analyses for decision-making. The Magnuson-Stevens Act is being amended to include guidelines for using the best scientific information available in fisheries management decisions. The Federal Register notice must explain how data and analyses were used, and provide reasons if any data was not used. The Secretary of Commerce must develop guidelines for using the best scientific information in fisheries management decisions within one year of the Act's enactment. Within 1 year of the Act's enactment, the Secretary of Commerce, in consultation with Regional Fishery Management Councils, must submit a report to Congress on cost reduction in fisheries management. The report will identify goals, methods for monitoring and enforcement, certify cost-effective methods, and explain why they may not be required. SEC. 6. COST SHARING.

Amendment to the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act regarding fee collection. The Secretary must conduct an analysis of costs to be recovered by the fee before collecting any fees. The analysis must be included in the fisheries management plan.
